docs.lead_paragraph: More than a century ago, Freud proposed that dreams concealed subconscious wishes and desires, a theory that has in recent decades fallen from scientific favor. A new study, however, may add weight to the idea that what people suppress during the day returns when they close their eyes at night.

headline.main: Dreams Ride On Freud's Royal Road, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Recent dream study, led by Dr Daniel M Wegner, Harvard University professor, suggests that thinking about something increases probability you will dream about it and repressing thoughts about something increases likelihood of dreaming about it even more; study, published in journal Psychological Science, does link subconscious thought with dreams, but does not completely support Freudian theory on matter (S)
docs.snippet: More than a century ago, Freud proposed that dreams concealed subconscious wishes and desires, a theory that has in recent decades fallen from scientific favor.    A new study, however, may add weight to the idea that what people suppress during the...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Should I Be Tested for Cancer?'' by Dr. H. Gilbert Welch. University of California Press, $19.95. Subtitled ''Maybe Not and Here's Why,'' this book by a professor at the Dartmouth Medical School addresses a mainstay of medical practice, disease screening, in a way that may disturb some people. Although Dr. Welch does not suggest that symptoms be ignored or that tests should not be run, he does argue there is another side to trying to find cancer early.
docs.abstract: Dr H Gilbert Welch book Should I Be Tested For Cancer describes problems involved with diagnostic testing for Cancer; discusses false-positives, human error and differences in tests; photo (S)
docs.snippet: ''Should I Be Tested for Cancer?'' by Dr. H. Gilbert Welch. University of California Press, $19.95.      Subtitled ''Maybe Not and Here's Why,'' this book by a professor at the Dartmouth Medical School addresses a mainstay of medical practice,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Joanne Koenig Coste concedes that she is a bit of a Pollyanna. ''It helps with what I do,'' said Ms. Coste, a consultant for institutions that treat patients with dementia and the author of ''Learning to Speak Alzheimer's.''

headline.main: A Wife Learns to See With Alzheimer's Eyes
headline.kicker: A CONVERSATION WITH: JOANNE KOENIG COSTE

docs.abstract: Interview with Joanne Koenig Coste, author of Learning to Speak Alzheimer's, describes her personal experience with husband Charles Koenig, who suffered from Alzheimer's, and her continued work in helping those individuals who care for afflicted; is credited with developing technique called habituation, which is adaptive life style that asks caregiver to live life style of patient not force Alzheimer's patient to try to adjust to rest of world; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Joanne Koenig Coste concedes that she is a bit of a Pollyanna.    ''It helps with what I do,'' said Ms. Coste, a consultant for institutions that treat patients with dementia and the author of ''Learning to Speak Alzheimer's.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Men with high blood pressure who drink moderate amounts of alcohol are less likely than nondrinkers to die of cardiovascular ailments like heart attacks and strokes, researchers reported yesterday. The study's findings suggest that moderate drinking not only has protective cardiovascular effects for the general population, as previous studies have shown, but that it is also protective for people who already have hypertension.
docs.abstract: Dr J Michael Gaziano, Brigham and Women's Hospital cardiologist and Harvard Medical School associate professor, leads study on effects of moderate drinking on high blood pressure; study, which was published in Archives of Internal Medicine and is based on data from Physician's Health Study, finds that men who drink one to six drinks weekly have 39 percent decreased risk of cardiovascular death compared to non-drinkers or those who drink very little (M)
docs.snippet: Men with high blood pressure who drink moderate amounts of alcohol are less likely than nondrinkers to die of cardiovascular ailments like heart attacks and strokes, researchers reported yesterday.     The study's findings suggest that moderate...

docs.lead_paragraph: If doctors admit making mistakes, will their patients be less likely to hire malpractice lawyers? Not necessarily, a study in the current Annals of Internal Medicine says. But the researchers also found that when doctors were candid about errors, patients felt better about them, and the patients were no more likely to pursue legal action than they were when doctors did not take responsibility.

headline.main: When Doctors Own Up to Errors

docs.abstract: Dr Kathleen M Mazor of Meyers Primary Care Institute, Worchester, Mass, leads study that shows when doctors admit mistakes to patients it does not diminish likelihood of legal action, but makes patients feel better about course of action; drawing; study, which was published in Annals of Internal Medicine, used series of fictitious situations between patient and doctor (S)
docs.snippet: If doctors admit making mistakes, will their patients be less likely to hire malpractice lawyers?    Not necessarily, a study in the current Annals of Internal Medicine says. But the researchers also found that when doctors were candid about errors,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies born when the weather is cold appear more likely to develop heart disease later in life, a new study says. The meaning of the link is not clear, but it may be that the cold weather sets a pattern of fat retention that carries on through life, the researchers write in the current issue of the journal Heart.

headline.main: Cold and Poor, a Double Peril

docs.abstract: Drs Richard Mitchell of University of Edinburgh and D A Lawlor of University of Bristol lead study that suggests season in which baby is born could affect adult risk for heart disease; finds that babies born in colder weather are more likely to develop coronary problems as adults; suggests that pattern of fat retention may be cause of trend; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Babies born when the weather is cold appear more likely to develop heart disease later in life, a new study says.    The meaning of the link is not clear, but it may be that the cold weather sets a pattern of fat retention that carries on through...

docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to quitting smoking, men and women may not be the same. A new study reports that among women, the effectiveness of nicotine patches intended to help people quit seems related to an individual's genetic makeup. In men, this does not appear to be the case.

headline.main: A Patch to Match Your Genes

docs.abstract: Dr Patricia Yudkin, Oxford University researcher, leads study that suggests that woman's genetic makeup influences effectiveness of patch designed to help quit smoking; study, which is published in BMJ, British medical journal, finds genetic background of men to be inconsequential in patch effectiveness (S)
docs.snippet: When it comes to quitting smoking, men and women may not be the same.    A new study reports that among women, the effectiveness of nicotine patches intended to help people quit seems related to an individual's genetic makeup. In men, this does not...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sinus infections are far less common than many people believe, researchers have found. A study at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., concluded that the incidence of sinusitis, a painful inflammation of the sinus cavities, might be highly exaggerated.
docs.abstract: Study by Dr Ron G Shashy, Dr Eric J Moore and Amy Weaver, finds under two percent of Americans have sinusitis, compared with previous research that suggested that 14 to 16 percent of Americans suffer from disorder; study, which was conducted at Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn, and published in Archives of Otolaryngology, is based on long-term national health study findings; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Sinus infections are far less common than many people believe, researchers have found.     A study at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., concluded that the incidence of sinusitis, a painful inflammation of the sinus cavities, might be highly...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask any woman who has had a difficult menopause if she thinks that Mrs. Rochester, locked in the attic in ''Jane Eyre,'' was actually insane. The answer is likely to be a resounding no. Poor Mrs. Rochester, living in an era before hormone therapy, has been on my mind lately, as I have tried, unsuccessfully, to wean myself off estrogen. Like me, she was probably dazed from too many sleepless nights, frightened by palpitations with no apparent cause and unable to concentrate on the simplest task or read a sentence from start to finish.

headline.main: Strokes or Insomnia? A Woman's Hormone Quandary

docs.abstract: Jane Gross gives personal narrative about decision to take estrogen for menopausal symptoms despite health studies that reveal increase in health risks for hormone replacement therapy; discusses symptoms and medical studies; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Ask any woman who has had a difficult menopause if she thinks that Mrs. Rochester, locked in the attic in ''Jane Eyre,'' was actually insane. The answer is likely to be a resounding no.    Poor Mrs. Rochester, living in an era before hormone therapy,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Name this product. The ingredients label says it contains the following: ''Water, ultrafiltered fat-free milk, calcium caseinate, cream, buttermilk, tricalcium phosphate, salt, disodium phosphate, mono- and di-glycerides, carrageenan, locust bean gum, natural flavor, sucralose (Splenda), acesulfame potassium, vitamin A palmitate and vitamin D3.'' No, it's not some weird dessert. It is Hood's Carb Countdown Dairy Beverage, a low-carb substitute for real skim milk that claims to provide ''75 percent less carbs and 50 percent more protein than whole milk.'' A half-gallon of the Hood's beverage sells for $3.99, compared with $1.48 for the same amount of real, unadulterated fat-free milk.

headline.main: Sane Weight Loss in a Carb-Obsessed World: High Fiber and Low Fat

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses new low-carbohydrate diet craze and products that cater to those wanting to follow diet; theory behind diet described; University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences and Central Arkansas Veterans Healthcare System study of low-fat, high-carbohydrate diets suggests people can lose weight, reduce body fat and maintain muscle mass without cutting carbs; attention to portion control and exercise continue to be major factors in losing weight and maintaining health; drawing (M)
